article.description: Chris Hill and Alan Anderson each scored 12 points as No. 15 Michigan State beat South Florida 65-56 Saturday, its 35th consecutive home victory over a non-conference opponent.
article.headline: Spartans make it 35 straight at home vs. non-Big Ten
article.linkText: No. 15 Spartans beat South Florida to extend streak
article.story:
EAST LANSING, Mich. (AP) -- Michigan State's stingy starting
defense did enough to allow the Spartans to coast the rest of the
way.

	   Chris Hill and Alan Anderson each scored 12 points as No. 15
Michigan State beat South Florida 65-56 Saturday, its 35th
consecutive home victory over a non-conference opponent.

	   The Spartans (7-2) held South Florida without a field goal for
the opening 11:25 as they took a 22-4 lead.

	   "There were times we made a good team look average, especially
at the start,'' Michigan State coach Tom Izzo said.

	   After the strong start, the Spartans seemed to go through the
motions. They couldn't build much upon their huge initial cushion,
but did maintain a double-digit lead until the final minute.

	   "There were some pretty impressive things we did at times,''
Izzo said. "I say it's my job to hold them to that for 40 minutes.

	   "I just felt the casualness we came out with in the second half
is something that we just can't have, especially against good
teams.''

	   Will McDonald and Brian Swift led South Florida (5-3) with 15
points apiece.

	   Izzo gave freshman forward Erazem Lorbek his first start in
place of senior Adam Ballinger, who started each of the previous
eight games and 25 of 27 last season. Izzo criticized Ballinger for
his scoreless play in a 26-point win over Loyola of Chicago on
Tuesday.

	   "It was something like an award,'' Lorbek said. "I was happy
Coach gave me an opportunity.''

	   Lorbek scored nine points, missing only one shot, and had four
rebounds. Ballinger scored two on 1-of-5 shooting.

	   "We've got to get Adam Ballinger playing better,'' Izzo said.
"We need him.''

	   Michigan State's Kelvin Torbert had 10 points and eight
rebounds.

	   After the Bulls missed their first 13 shots, they made two
straight to pull within 13 points.

	   "That wasn't exactly the start we were looking for,'' South
Florida coach Seth Greenberg said.

	   Michigan State led 33-17 at halftime. South Florida cut its
deficit to 38-28 with 15:31 left, but the Spartans ended the threat
with seven straight points.

	   "We got one run when got it to 10 and we had the ball, but we
didn't seize that moment,'' Greenberg said.

	   Michigan State could not turn the game into a blowout because it
shot just 38 percent overall.

	   "We are too up and down,'' Michigan State's Aloysius Anagonye
said. "The first 10 minutes, we played our best from the whole
year. But unfortunately, we didn't hold onto that, so we've got a
lot to work on.''

	   Michigan State football coach John L. Smith, who was hired
Thursday, was welcomed with a standing ovation at halftime. Smith
said he looked forward to playing "that school down the road,''
referring to Michigan.
